title: 105_hr3157
content: The "Teachers in the Classroom Act" may be cited as the short title. The findings section is included in the Act. Congress finds that enrollment in elementary and secondary schools is at record levels, with an expected increase of over a million students in 1998. The increase in student enrollment will continue for the next decade, particularly affecting high poverty urban and rural areas and states with rapid population growth. Schools will need to expand to accommodate the growing number of students. Schools will need to hire 150,000 additional teachers in the next decade to address the increase in student enrollment. Research shows that students in smaller classes learn more in the early grades and continue to outperform their peers even after returning to normal-sized classrooms. It is crucial to adequately educate and prepare students for the future and global economy. Congress must provide resources to improve the learning environment for students, hire new teachers without increasing bureaucracy, and fund positions to keep pace with growing enrollment and reduce classroom sizes. The grant program is established to provide resources for improving the learning environment, hiring new teachers, and reducing classroom sizes. The Secretary of Education can award grants to Governors for hiring teachers to reduce overcrowded classes. Governors must apply to receive the grant, and local educational agencies must establish a trust fund for the funds received. The Act requires funds to be deposited in a trust fund account and used to hire new teachers within 2 years. The agency must follow accounting practices set by the Governor, allow access to records, and ensure a net gain in teachers. Personnel hired must be reviewed annually for qualifications. The agency must hire qualified personnel for a one-year period, repay any unspent funds to the State within 27 months, use funds to supplement, not supplant, non-Federal sources for student education, and apply for funding annually from the Governor. SEC. 4. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. Each State receives funds based on the average number of children aged 5 through 17. Unused funds are reallocated to other States. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. The agency must hire qualified personnel, repay unspent funds, supplement non-Federal sources for student education, and apply for annual funding from the Governor. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. A Governor can withhold payments to a local educational agency for noncompliance with section 3(c) after 60 days notice. The agency must increase teachers or qualified personnel to continue receiving funds. SEC. 6. PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION. A Governor receiving a grant under this Act must select local educational agencies based on the need to alleviate overcrowded classes. They must evaluate and report on the funds used by the agencies annually and can use up to 2 percent of the funds for administrative costs. Additionally, Governors can use funds for innovative teaching programs. A Governor receiving funds under this Act can allocate up to 10 percent for innovative teaching programs, such as teacher training incentives and alternate certification procedures. The Secretary of Education must report annually on program effectiveness and make recommendations for program continuity. SEC. 7. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not provide tenure to personnel hired under it. SEC. 8. DEFINITION. Defines "local educational agency," "State," and "Secretary." SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Act are as follows: $500,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, $1,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $1,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, $2,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, and $2,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2003.
